title: 03 Assessing Performance
summary: Don critiques competency-based education's failure to develop rigorous performance assessment systems. Using his high school shop class experience (40% theory, 40% practical, 20% attitude), he argues attitudes are undervalued—they're actually the most important employment factor. He rejects averaging theory and practical grades, comparing it to averaging someone's comfort by averaging head-in-freezer and feet-in-oven temperatures. Don proposes performance criteria (Quality, Quantity, Problem-Solving, Leadership, Supervision) with contextual levels derived from real-life occupational standards. His conclusion emphasizes that performance assessment remains education's uncharted territory despite its critical importance.
content_preview:
Assessing Performance




Much has been said about competency or outcome-based education.  It is one of the major educational issues of our day; it also has its critics.  Many of the criticisms, I find, apply to a version of CBE that is quite different from mine.  Such versions usually suggest a rigid, narrow and mechanical approach.  They are limited to a restricted list of outcomes, or they fail to address the whole area of standards and assessment.

Criteria and approaches for determining competencies have been described and approaches to their identification are many and varied.  In fact, books have been written on the subject.  A major gap exists in the literature, however, related to the assessment of trainee performance.  Performance assessment remains largely uncharted and some would say “un-chartable” waters.

When I took “shop courses” as part of my high school program, I recall being graded on both theory and practical work.  The theory was a result of my tests and examinations throughout the year.  My practical mark was for the projects which I had completed.  My final grade was based upon theory, practical and attitude.  The breakdown, as I recall, was 40% for theory, 40% for practical and 20% for attitude.  I’m told that, at least in some institutions, similar criteria are still in use.

It is difficult to defend the practice of averaging of school grades at any time, but there is no defense for averaging ratings for theory and practice I order to arrive at levels of performance.  Neither  can one, in good conscience, average ratings of a number of performance tasks.  Averaging theory and practice may be likened to determining  a person’s comfort level by averaging the temperature of a person with his head in a refrigerator and feet in an oven.  On average, he is comfortable.

title: 05 CANADA COLLEGE
summary: Don proposes a national "Canada College"—not a teaching institution but a credit bank aggregating learning from schools, universities, colleges, work, self-study, and life experience into recognized credentials. He notes BC's Open Learning Agency operates a limited version; New Zealand has established a Qualification Authority. CANADA COLLEGE




Schools no longer have a monopoly on the delivery of education and training.  Employers, labor unions, trade and professional associations, consulting agencies, and many others now deliver courses, workshops, and other training sessions to employees, members and the public at large.  Some agencies deliver a series of courses which result in a credential; other organizations simply deliver stand-alone short courses.  Some large US corporations offer their own degree programs.




The trend towards a multiplicity of delivery agencies is now well established in Canada and, given the current constitutional discussions, the proliferation will likely continue.  Canadians who are life long learners will have even more choices from which to choose training, including creating their own.  To this we can add self study and the rich experiences of participation and leadership in community activities.  Lifelong learners, therefore, can end up with a large number of certificates recognizing participation or achievement in individual courses but none which recognizes the continuous and collective achievement of the learner.




While educational institutions may consider previous educational and other experience when accepting students, they are not very anxious to and less than generous in giving credit for education dissimilar to that which they offer in their own institution.  Some schools are even reluctant to give credit for courses taken through their own extension departments.  A sheepskin curtain separates credit and non credit courses.

title: 09 Finding the key to competency rating
summary: Article published in CVA Journal on competency-based education, proposing performance-based criteria for rating competency levels rather than traditional theory/practical breakdowns. Don draws on his high school shop course experience and argues for criteria including quality, quantity, problem-solving, leadership, and dependability. Reflects his influential thinking on competency-based education that shaped Holland College's instructional model.
content_preview:
Finding the key to competency rating




A formula based on an employer’s criteria for doing the job works




Much has been said about competency-based education.  Criteria for determining competencies have been described and models for undertaking competency analysis are in existence.  Little attention has been given, however, to the rating of competency levels.

When I took “shop courses” as part of my high school program, I recall being graded on both theory and practical work.  The theory was the result of my tests and examinations throughout the year.  My practical mark was based upon three factors: namely, quality, quantity and attitude.  The breakdown, as I recall, was 40 percent for quality, 40 percent for quantity and 20 percent for attitude.  The practical and theory grades were averaged to five a final course mark.  I’m told that, at least in some institutions, similar criteria are still in use.  Are they still valid for rating performance?  Let us look at some performance-based criteria.

Rating of performance must occur in some context.  Performance-based ratings measure the application of knowledge, not just the knowledge itself.  It is preferable that the same criteria be used both in school and at work.  The system must allow individuals to progress and should, therefore, allow for increased levels of performance based on experience.

Quality: the accuracy with which a person can consistently perform a task.

Quantity: the speed with which a person is able to perform a  task to an acceptable level of quality.

Problem solving: the ability to overcome unexpected circumstances in order to perform a task.

Leadership: the ability to lead others in the performance of a skill or task.

Dependability: the ability to consistently perform a task at an acceptable level of speed and accuracy without (or a minimum of) supervision.

title: 1 Graduations
summary: Don challenges the age-based graduation system, asking why students with different entry levels and learning rates must graduate simultaneously. He proposes competency-based graduation allowing students to earn diplomas upon meeting requirements regardless of time required. Drawing from his experience monitoring self-paced Holland College programs, Don notes that students completing programs early showed no performance degradation. He argues that making time the variable rather than competency would motivate students, benefit those learning quickly, and incentivize achievement. While acknowledging this complicates administration, Don asserts the pedagogical and motivational benefits justify the restructuring.
content_preview:
July 9, 2010




Editor

Charlottetown Guardian

Charlottetown, PEI




Dear Sir:

Graduations




I enjoyed the recent insert in the Guardian on student graduations. Congratulations to all

graduates. The insert brought back many memories. I was one of 12 graduates in the first rural

high school built in New Brunswick more years ago than I care to recall.




It seems odd to me that, in 2010, we still do not have a school system that allows students to

graduate when they meet the requirements. Students enter school at different levels and learn

at different rates while in school; given that they take essentially the same program how come

they all complete at the same time? Why not establish clear graduation requirements, award

diplomas when students meet the requirements, wish them well and let them be on their way.




A few years ago, I monitored some students following a self-paced program at Holland College.

It was nominally of two years duration; some students finished 4- 5 months early without any

measurable lowering of performance. Allowing people to learn at their own pace (they do so

anyway regardless of school schedules) could be a major incentive in its own right. Giving prizes

and awards for meeting standards early would likely be an additional incentive.




Making time the variable may complicate the life of school administrators, and maybe even

teachers, but it would sure put a new spring in the step of most students.







Sincerely










Don Glendenning































Appeared in Charlottetown Guardian on July 73, 2070 as "A new approach to Graduation"

Editor, 

Charlottetown Guardian

Charlottetown, PEI	




Dear Sir:

Another option




For many years employers used high school graduation as a measure when hiring new employees.  Now, however, employers tell me that a graduation diploma doesn’t provide the assurance it once did, especially as a measure of basic communication and math skills; perhaps it never actually did.  




In view of this, it’s time for an independent assessment service or centre where people, young or old, could have their skills assessed.  Different employers may have different requirements, but the testing service, I am sure, could easily accommodate any differences.  If a person meets an employer’s requirement, problem solved; if a person doesn’t meet requirements, presumably s/he can return to school and further study




Tests of basic skills are already available on PEI at Holland College and Workplace Learning PEI, and likely there are others.  In fact, I am told that some employers in the West require Islanders to take tests on PEI before heading there to work.  I am not suggesting a massive new testing program but, for people who need to know their skill levels, a separate testing service deserves consideration.







Sincerely

Editor

title: 2014 Employers have choices
summary: Don notes that employers no longer rely solely on high school diplomas as hiring criteria, seeking assurance of basic math and communication skills. He proposes an independent assessment service where individuals could have skills tested, with results useful for both job seekers and employers. He references existing testing services at Holland College and Workplace Learning PEI, noting that Western Canadian employers already require PEI workers to take pre-screening tests. This service would address skills verification without creating a massive new bureaucratic program.
content_preview:
November 24, 2014




Editor, Charlottetown Guardian

Charlottetown, PEI	




Dear Sir:

Another option




For many years employers used high school graduation as a measure when hiring new employees.  Now, however, employers tell me that a graduation diploma doesn’t provide the assurance it once did, especially as a measure of basic communication and math skills; perhaps it never actually did.  




In view of this, it’s time for an independent assessment service or centre where people, young or old, could have their skills assessed.  Different employers may have different requirements, but the testing service, I am sure, could easily accommodate any differences.  If a person meets an employer’s requirement, problem solved; if a person doesn’t meet requirements, presumably s/he can return to school and further study




Tests of basic skills are already available on PEI at Holland College and Workplace Learning PEI, and likely there are others.  In fact, I am told that some employers in the West require Islanders to take tests on PEI before heading there to work.  I am not suggesting a massive new testing program but, for people who need to know their skill levels, a separate testing service deserves consideration.







Sincerely




Don Glendenning

A long time student of education

title: 2016-10 Adams
summary: Don's tribute to Bob Adams, a Nova Scotia colleague who introduced Holland College to DACUM (Developing A Curriculum) methodology during its foundational year. Don recounts Holland College's initial traditional delivery model and deliberate search for better alternatives through institution visits and innovation research. He credits DACUM's simplicity, analytical rigor, single-page competency presentation, and rating system as transformative to the college's mission, and notes its international adoption, though sometimes diverging from Adams' original vision.
content_preview:
Dear Editor:




A friend of Holland College




Yesterday I learned that a former colleague had died; he was living in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia.  Few readers would have met him but many readers would have felt his impact.  You see, Bob Adams introduced Holland College to DACUM charts.  Employers may remember the three- day brainstorming sessions; students will likely remember the large sheet identifying the competencies of their chosen career.  




Although Holland College operated on a traditional delivery model during our first year, we actively searched for something better.  Step one was the development of a statement of beliefs; step 2 was a search for a delivery model to match.  We visited a number of institutions and gathered information about other innovative projects both in Canada and the US, and then one day, we visited the Nova NewStart Corporation in Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, talked with Bob Adams and observed the DACUM model in use.  




DACUM was a great match; it had many of the elements Holland College was looking for; in particular we were impressed with the simplicity of the model, the analysis process, the single page presentation, and the rating system.   Since then DACUM has gone international; unfortunately, not always as Bob envisaged it.

 

I write this note to express my sympathy to Bob’s wife, Coleen, and family, to recognize his contribution to Holland College and to call attention to DACUM, a great Canadian achievement.

	 

Sincerely




Don Glendenning

title: 5 Governance- consolidated 2
summary: Extensive May 18, 2013 treatment of school governance reflecting Don's long-standing interest dating to his influential role shaping Holland College's unicameral governance model in 1969. Don defines governance as "who makes what decisions, and in what manner." He identifies underlying confusions between education/schooling and credentials/qualifications. The paper extensively documents that research shows direct relationship between school autonomy and student performance (citing OECD PISA data). Don emphasizes teachers should serve as "educational family doctors" with accountability for learner outcomes. He proposes clear decision-making assignments: learners/parents select schools and programs, teachers make professional decisions for assigned learners, principals focus on instructional leadership, trustees/superintendents operate schools, Deputy Ministers ensure quality education for all Islanders. Includes detailed Albertan school board decision examples and PEI trustee responsibilities. Advocates for immediate changes: consolidate educational responsibilities, delegate administrative decisions, clarify principal roles, assign student decisions to teachers, establish independent qualification authority. Later "Thoughts on School Governance" section dated May 25, 2012 emphasizes governance model could remove change barriers when combined with professional freedom and accountability. Don notes government role should be leadership, planning, standards-setting, certification, funding, monitoring—not school operation.

title: 500 Beyond Knowledge
summary: Don reflects on his journey toward competency-based education, tracing influences from S.R. Laycock's learning models through his experience in vocational training and curriculum planning. He articulates the progression from traditional textbook-driven instruction to work-based, competency-focused approaches. Central to his vision is Benjamin Bloom's taxonomy and his observation that public schools remain stuck at the comprehension level rather than advancing students through analysis, synthesis, and evaluation. Don argues that vocational programs excel precisely because they clearly define performance levels in workplace-relevant language, distinguishing them from academic programs.

Designing training programs, at least vocational ones, took me beyond textbooks and disciplines, and into the community and work place.  Text books come later, if at all.

Experience in vocational education where the first task of the teacher therefore is to find out what practitioners do, and then to prepare students to do likewise.

Detailed curriculum planning required to ensure that the training being offered addresses skills, knowledge and attitudes required for a chosen career.

My involvement in teacher education especially in the teaching of methods and curriculum development.

My exposure to discussions about nationwide standards so that skilled workers can meet qualifications required in any jurisdiction.

title: 500 College and University
summary: Don recounts the founding context of Holland College during PEI's "Unholy War" university merger controversy in the late 1960s. He explains his conviction that PEI needed a technical college distinct from university education, one providing training for occupations both within and beyond the island. This essay defines the philosophical differences between colleges and universities: colleges emphasize applied knowledge, intensive specialty study, field-derived content, employment success metrics, integrated theory and practice, and industry partnerships. Don argues against subordinating college curriculum to university transfer requirements, maintaining that quality college programs should prioritize relevance to employment and community needs rather than university credit transfer.

College and University







I was still living in Ottawa during “The Unholy War that rocked Prince Edward Island’ in the late 1960’s.  Reaction to the merger of the two universities was noisy; as for a technical college, I am told that educators saw no pressing need.  As I understand it, it was felt that the addition of a few courses at the Provincial Vocational Institute, or even the addition of diploma courses at the local university, would be more than adequate.  Given the latter view, expectations for the new institution were not great.  Forty years later, I am happy to report that the view has dramatically changed.




Growing up on the east coast of New Brunswick, I was painfully aware of the exodus of young people for Toronto and points west.  Most making the journey found work but  for many that work was low paid and heavy; too  few accessed well paid jobs or opportunities in the then emerging economy.  The focus of jobs for graduates of the new College became an issue.  To what extent should the College limit itself to providing training for occupations not found in PEI or where opportunities on PEI were limited?  Debate on the issue was neither long nor vigorous – but it did take place.  It was taken for granted by the new Governors, that Holland College would provide training for Islanders wherever their employment prospects would take them.




Modern industry requires highly skilled people.  Without matching skills, people will not find work, and without a pool of skilled workers, industry will steer clear of PEI as a placed to do business.  Changes in industry would soon find their way to PEI; PEI needed to get ready.

title: 500 Continuous Intake
summary: Don criticizes traditional education's time-based administrative system where learners must begin and end on fixed schedules regardless of learning progress. He argues schools should operate more like hospitals, keeping students under care until they reach acceptable performance levels. At Holland College, Don experimented with continuous or staggered entry and exit, allowing students to begin programs when spaces became available rather than on rigid semesters. He acknowledges implementation challenges, particularly with small one- or two-instructor programs, but maintains the concept's validity. The essay reflects tension between administrative convenience and pedagogical effectiveness.
content_preview:
Continuous Intake







Elsewhere in these my musings, I referred to the fact that education is driven by an out-dated administrative system where time on task is the constant and performance the variable.  The system focuses on groups not individuals and forces learners to begin and end studies, not based on learning progress but at the sound of a bell.  Teachers are required to fashion their teaching to fit available time rather than the system accommodating the needs of students. Learning theory collides with administrative practice and administration usually wins. The rigidity of the system, in my view, is a major deterrent to change. 




The reverse should be the case.  Doctors keep you under care or in the hospital until you are better; teachers should keep you in their care until you perform at an acceptable level.




Elsewhere I identified a number of beliefs or principles followed in designing the Holland College approach to learning and teaching.  One was the students should be able to enter or exit a program on their own time – that is, make time, not achievement, the variable.  Exiting on completion was not a problem,  except that it made graduation exercises difficult to organize; staggered or continuous intake, however, was different.

Dear Editor:

School autonomy

I was asked recently about the lack of autonomy in our school system. 

As readers may know, among community colleges, Holland College was known for the degree of autonomy in operational matters.  That was a deliberate action taken by the College Planning Committee during the drafting of the Holland College Act. A similar level of autonomy should be given to public schools.

The OECD, who administers PISA tests, tells us that students from schools with autonomy in their day to day operations, do better on PISA tests.  Furthermore, a paper by Mathieu Bedard, Montreal Economic Institute also recommends increased school autonomy and accountability. July 12, 2014




Editor, Charlottetown Guardian

Charlottetown, PEI	




Dear Sir:

Education moving outside school 




Employers need employees who can read and write but having a high school graduation diploma doesn’t provide that information; a copy of transcripts probably won’t tell either.  But there is a new tool on the market that may help; it’s called a TOWES Test; it’s worth having a look.




TOWES (Test of Workplace Essential Skills)  was developed at Bow Valley College in Alberta and tests a person’s level on nine essential skills, reading text, document use, numeracy, writing, oral communication, working with others, continuous learning, thinking skills and computer skills.  These are the weaknesses most often mentioned by employers.  One thing I liked about it is that, unlike traditional school exams, it gives levels rather than simply ranking students.




I know that it is used at Holland College and I believe with some other adult training programs; it may also be used in the public schools but I have not aware of it.  If it lives up to its reputation, it may supply employers with information they need, and even replace the requirement for graduation diplomas.

A culture of fear




People often mention a “culture of fear” in public education; if that’s so, we should do something about it.  Having read Donald Savoie’s recent book, What Government is good at, I have a better understanding of that concern.  Personally, I’ve not encountered any pressure to withhold my point of view.  On the other hand, I have encountered people who, because they depend upon government for contracts, feel that they should refrain from being active in Education 20.20 Inc.  As one retired official said, “If a person plans to live and work in the field of education on PEI, don’t expect them to come to your meetings.”

If the Department were to  broaden its mandate, the advice of a management consulting firm would be in order.







Sincerely,

Restructuring the School System

are assessed, students tend to perform better.

title: Outside the box today
summary: Don addresses three major challenges to educational reform. First, he advocates for continuous intake programs where students enter/exit based on achievement rather than fixed calendar periods, contrasting rigid time-based systems with outcome-based approaches like those at Holland College. He argues that staggered enrollment supports diverse learning rates and real-world employment patterns. Second, Don discusses Prior Learning Assessment (PLA), emphasizing it should be integrated into ongoing teaching rather than treated as separate gatekeeping. This inverted model capitalizes on learner interests, reduces first-year dropout rates, equips early departures with employable skills, and reflects actual work-world experience. title: Tyranny of time
summary: (153 words):** Don critiques schools' time-driven organization prioritizing administrative convenience over learning needs. Fixed school calendars, instruction hours, subject timing, and class schedules ignore fundamental learning reality: individual learning rates vary significantly. Current assessment measures achievement within fixed time rather than time required for achievement—like measuring race distance covered rather than race completion time. Don advocates inverting the equation: make graduation requirements constant and time variable. Students meeting requirements graduate on schedule; those needing support continue studying until achieving graduation standards. Don proposes offering extra weeks for struggling students rather than forcing advancement regardless of readiness. He suggests this flexibility—accommodating learning-rate differences—might dramatically increase graduation rates. This philosophy influenced Holland College's continuous-intake model and Don's persistent critique of rigid time-based schedules subordinating learning reality to administrative efficiency.

Schools are time based institutions.  The system sets the number of days schools are open, the number of hours of instruction each day, days to be made up because of storms, the length of time available on a subject before you must move to another, they keep attendance, time missed may result in the lowering of a grade, teacher pay scales are related to years of training and years of experience.  I can think of no other sector that is so driven by time.




The curriculum carves up subjects to be learned into subjects, units and lessons.  




Rate of learning, on the other hand, is unique to each individual.  It is generally understood that most students can learn most subjects to the same level if given time.  




Learners enter school and are told, here is what is to be learned and here are the dates and times that teachers are available to help you learn.  And as you know, you are measured on ho much you learn in the time available.




It is a bit like conducting a race and, instead of measuring the time it takes each to run the course, it measures how far you can run in a set time.
